article.title: CO2 infrared emission as a diagnostic of planet-forming regions of disks

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the color coding of the lines connecting the vibrational levels in Figure 1 represent?
choices: The energy difference between the vibrational levels.
The strength of the transition.
The wavelength range of the transition.
The rotational quantum number J.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the dominant cause of the broadness of the 15 µm feature in the CO2 spectrum shown in Figure 2?
choices: The Doppler broadening due to the high temperature.
The high rotational excitation temperature.
The Fermi splitting of the bending and stretching modes.
The large number of vibrational states included in the model.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main reason why the CO2 Q-branch is intrinsically narrower than the HCN Q-branch at similar wavelengths, as seen in Figure 3?
choices: CO2 has a lower rotational constant than HCN.
CO2 has a higher critical density than HCN.
The change in the rotational constant between the ground and excited vibrational states is smaller for CO2.
CO2 is less abundant in the inner disk regions than HCN.

multiple_choice_question.text: What happens to the 4.3 µm CO2 emission band when the density is significantly below its critical density and no radiation field is present, as seen in Figure 4?
choices: The band becomes much stronger.
The band becomes much weaker.
The band becomes broader.
The band shows multiple Q-branches.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the parameter γ represent in Formula (1), describing the surface density profile of the disk?
choices: The dust opacity.
The scale height of the disk.
The power-law index of the surface density profile.
The characteristic radius of the disk.
